attributes.comment:
The proposed fees are outside the possible range of the majority of our clients.
We primarily serve refugees and immigrants who fill the ranks of minimum hourly
rate workers. For instance, a person who earns $7.00/hr, earns approximately
$14,000/yr. They may fall slightly above or below the poverty level, depending on
their family size. They barely survive paying their rent, utilities, food and clothing.
We find that people now are discouraged from filing for citizenship or adjustment
of status due to immigration fees. Often there are other, collateral fees such as
required medical forms, photos, travel for fingerprints etc, so that the total costs
are prohibitive. To increase fees by a small percentage is reasonable. To
increase, in some cases by 100% or more, is not reasonable and not affordable.
Especially considering that people frequently have to file petitions more than once
before they receive the benefit due them.
It is the perception of the clients, that BCIS is attempting to pass the costs of
possible legalization of undocumented individuals from Immigration Reform on ALL
immigrants.
If fees increase by such a significant amount, it is expected that fee waivers will
become much more prevalent. Has Homeland Security considered the impact of
substantial increase in numbers of fee waivers? Also, will the poverty level for fee
waivers increase to take in the low-income employed person who currently does
not qualify under the existing fee waiver?
In summary, this is not a reasonable proposal. Thank you.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Wendy Hernandez, World Relief Spokane
